channel.title: Elizabeth Rghebi – Baraza
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: Libya’s Sufi Character Cannot Be Erased
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rghebi
item.description: Multiple attacks on Sufi religious and historical sites last week highlight two threats to Libya’s democratic transition: Islamic extremism and the failure of the government to take action. On 25 August, Salafist extremists destroyed a Sufi shrine and library in Zlitan. The following day, Salafist extremists attacked the Sha’ab Mosque in Tripoli, which contained the graves of revered Sufi … Continue reading Libya’s Sufi Character Cannot Be Erased →

item.title: Walid Jumblatt: Can He Have His Baklawa and Eat it Too?
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rghebi
item.description: In March 2010, he left a national dialogue session with other Lebanese politicians, because he was “sleepy and hungry.” In December 2010, responding to alleged statements attributed to him by Wikileaks, he proposed the use of “carrier pigeons or horseback mail, which is more secure.” I have wanted to write something focusing on Walid Jumblatt … Continue reading Walid Jumblatt: Can He Have His Baklawa and Eat it Too? →

item.title: Libyan Media: In Chaos or Right Where it Should Be?
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rghebi
item.description: After 42 years under the tight grip of Muammar al-Gaddafi, Libya is not only experiencing a political revolution but also a media revolution. The tightly controlled state-run media of the Gaddafi regime allowed no room for free expression or criticism. As the revolution which began in February of 2011 spread across Libya, numerous media outlets … Continue reading Libyan Media: In Chaos or Right Where it Should Be? →
